subject: RE: [junit] Best practices for testing approximate equivalence?
msgSnippet: More to the point, you can t compare double and float primitives WITHOUT specifying a tolerance. assertEquals(final String failMessage, final double expected,
messageBody:
More to the point, you can't compare double and float primitives WITHOUT
specifying a tolerance.

assertEquals(final String failMessage, final double expected, final double
actual, final double tolerance);

assertEquals(final String failMessage, final float expected, final float
actual, final float tolerance);

There is no other way to do this with assertEquals(). You may have been doing
this:

final double expected = 6.7234d;
final double actual = 6.7234d;
assertTrue( expected == actual );

If you were, then use assertEquals() instead. :)

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
President, Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's write software that people understand.
